article.title: A Survey of XML Tree Patterns

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements is **FALSE** regarding Figure 2?
choices: Figure 2(a) represents a data tree with books described by their title, author(s), editor, year of publication, and summary.
Figure 2(b) showcases a tree pattern that selects only book titles.
Formula F in Figure 2(b) specifies that the author of the selected book must not be "Jill".
Figure 2(c) represents the output witness tree containing data from a single book that matches the criteria in Figure 2(b).

multiple_choice_question.text: What key difference exists between the generalized tree pattern (GTP) in Figure 3 and the tree pattern (TP) in Figure 2(b)?
choices: The GTP uses solid lines to denote optional edges, while the TP uses dotted lines.
The GTP includes a predicate in its formula to exclude books written by "Jill".
The GTP can match books even if they lack a "year" element, unlike the TP.
The GTP groups multiple nodes under a single parent, while the TP does not.

multiple_choice_question.text: The annotated pattern tree (APT) in Figure 4 utilizes the "-" annotation. What does this annotation specify in the context of matching?
choices: It allows the pattern to match books with zero or one author.
It allows the pattern to match books with one or many authors.
It allows the pattern to match only books with a single author.
It allows the pattern to match books with zero or many authors.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 10 illustrates the minimization of a tree pattern (TP). What is the primary goal of TP minimization?
choices: To simplify the visual representation of the TP for easier understanding.
To identify and eliminate redundant nodes in the TP to improve matching efficiency.
To add integrity constraints to the TP to ensure data consistency.
To rearrange nodes in the TP for better aesthetic appeal.
